"It was a dark and stormy night. The rain pounded against the windowpane like a thousand tiny drummers. I sat at my desk, trying to write a story, but the words just wouldn't come.

As I stared out into the darkness, I wondered if anyone had ever written a good story on a night like this. I thought about all the famous authors who must have sat in similar situations, struggling to find their muse.

Just then, my phone rang. It was my friend Shuji, calling from Japan. 'What's up?' he asked, his voice cheerful despite the time difference.

I told him about my writer's block and he chuckled knowingly. 'Ah,' he said, 'you're just experiencing the Japanese concept of "mu."'

I had to look it up online. It turned out that 'mu' was a Japanese word that referred to the state of being without thoughts or emotions. It was like a blank slate, devoid of any feelings or ideas.

Shuji explained that sometimes, you just have to let go and be in a state of 'mu.' Don't think about writing; don't try to create anything. Just sit back, relax, and let the universe do its thing.

I tried it out, and surprisingly, it worked! The words started flowing effortlessly onto the page. I wrote all night, fueled by the storm outside and the calmness within.

The next morning, I read over what I had written, and it was like a whole new world had opened up to me. The darkness of the night had given way to the light of creation.

From then on, I made sure to keep a little bit of 'mu' in my life. When the going gets tough, I sit back, relax, and let the universe do its thing."

(Note: 'Mu' is indeed a Japanese word that roughly translates to "nothingness" or "emptiness". It's often used as a concept in Zen Buddhism and other Eastern philosophies to describe a state of being free from thoughts, emotions, and ego.)

Drinks are also a breeze - we'll just need to purchase enough bottled beverages for everyone, which can even be done on the day of the party if needed. While we're out getting drinks, we can grab decorations too, so that shouldn't take more than a day with some help. The most labor-intensive part will be setting up the gym, but we can't start on that until after midterms since it requires a lot of people. Luckily, the Student Council has offered to lend a hand. Figuring out the party's entertainment and making it happen will likely be the biggest challenge. On a practical note, it's a good idea to prepare a shopping list in advance to avoid overlooking anything important.
